author: ZarrCon
body:
One way I like to visualize dividend growth investing is by using Visa as an example. A lot of people might look at its current yield of 0.70% and think it would be a terrible dividend stock to own because they yield is so low. But when you look at the actual dividend amounts things start to become a lot more clear.

In 2009, Visa paid a dividend of $0.10 a share. In 2019 they paid a dividend of $1.00 a share. Visa's stock price was around $20 in 2009, so if we use that as our cost basis, the current dividend yield we'd be receiving from shares purchased in 2009 would be 5% (known as yield on cost). So basically even though Visa currently yields 0.70% to anyone buying today, that doesn't mean everyone holding shares is making 0.70% on their investment. 

This is one of the reasons Warren Buffet has been so successful over the years. For example, his cost basis on Coca Cola is $3.25 per share, and the stock currently pays a dividend of $1.64 per share. This means Buffet's yield on cost is over 50%. He invested $1.3B in KO back in the late 80s and early 90s, and will now collect $654 million in income from the stock this year alone.

author: StarWolf478
body:
As someone that has debated whether or not I should buy Square stock for a while now and has come close to buying at times, I can tell you that Jack Dorsey's interview with congress pushed me more towards the "don't buy" side.

Management is one of the top 5 most important qualities that I look for when deciding which stocks to buy and I got a very bad impression of Jack Dorsey after watching his interview with congress. For a while now, I've heard some people say that Jack Dorsey is "the next Steve Jobs"; well, I did not see anything close to "the next Steve Jobs" in that interview; Steve Jobs would have handled that situation far better. Dorsey didn't even come across as an average CEO; he came across as "THIS bum is the CEO of multi-billion dollar companies? WTF?" Dorsey looked like he was drugged out of his mind during the interview and did not come across as the intelligent leader that I want to see in companies that I invest in.

From what I've seen in YouTube comments of those interviews, many other people got the same bad impression of Jack Dorsey from those interviews that I did, so I can definitely see how this would negatively effect the stocks of his companies. It has certainly kept me from buying.

author: cbus20122
body:
>that if we’re faced with low growth and inflation expectations then this is where assets should be priced.

Based on what model? Low growth + inflation implies higher real rates, which imply strong tightening of financial conditions. You think in that scenario stocks are priced rationally?

The whole narrative that stocks are expensive because yields are low should work both ways. If yields rise (due to inflation) stocks should then see a lot of selling, especially in longer duration exposures.

Low growth + inflation expectations, if that were to actually occur, implies heavy P/E contraction in the coming years. That's assuming those expectations are actually discounting the correct things which they very well may not be.

That either gives you a 1970's type scenario, in which bonds get wrecked and stocks tread water relative to inflation, or more of a depression type deflationary scenario, in which case stocks **surely** are not priced properly.

The issue with any inflationary scenario is that if it truly gets going in any form (scenario 1 here where we see something similar to the 70's), we're in for a lot more trouble than we can handle. There is far too much debt for the economy to handle inflation pressures, and any increase in bond yields will result in massive tightening of financial conditions. That scenario likely ends up leading into a deflationary spiral in the end. There is a reason we saw a 20% drawdown in 2018. The global economy simply can't handle rate increases which inflation would cause.

As for any comparison to the the 1970's, the macro environment then was far different than now - they had very strong demographics, very low non-public debt, and the inflation was largely based on **demand** along with a few supply shocks\*\*.\*\* Globally, we couldn't be more opposite of that right now.

Overall, the only particularly great argument for valuations right now is that there simply are no other great alternatives, and there has been no need to de-leverage due to the ability to lower rates and keep yields at or below zero globally. This, and the fact that unlike 08', governments are doing their best to not allow defaults of major companies, which has kept the market at least relatively orderly and prevented forced de-leveraging.

In my personal opinion, the trigger for any real longer-term recession or depression of any sort will come from inflation rising past an ever-falling threshold of growth. The "level" of financial tightening represented by yields has been falling for 40 years.

* In 08', they over-tightened to the point where 5% caused the debt overburden to blow things up.
* In 2018, 2.5% was getting far too tight, mandating emergency rate cuts going into 2019.

Now? Debt burdens have expanded drastically post-covid, and banks are not lending very much at all. This causes a drawdown in supply, which increases overall inflation on a longer-term basis. So you get a scenario where the economy likely couldn't handle bond rates much past 1% (and that's being incredibly generous), yet the conditions for future inflation **relative to real growth** are growing.

I certainly don't think the financial system is going to blow up tomorrow by any means, but we are getting close to the boundaries of the financial system to keep operating in the same way it has over the last 40 years, and any significant change, which becomes more likely the closer we get to those boundaries implies strong turbulence in the next 3-5 years.

author: Logophi1e
body:
If it’s wasn’t overvalued then yes I would get tired of hearing it. But it is and so I’m not. People only get frustrated hearing this because they want their stocks to keep going up up up all the time which is just not sustainable, and is what has been happening. Valuations are extremely high right now not because the companies are actually worth that much but because most investors expect the government and the fed to continuously pump the market. Reminds me of the “unsinkable” Titanic. It’s delusional and needs to come back to reality. Not saying we need an insane crash but there shouldn’t be an expectation that “stocks only go up”. If it weren’t for QE and government stimulus, the market wouldn’t be anywhere close to where it is today and you can’t deny that. That is why saying it is overvalued is completely reasonable and actually logical.

Edit: so because I changed one letter in the word stocks my entire post was removed? Very funny. Auto mods are a joke because they fail to understand context and instead remove posts simply for the use of certain words. All my points still stand.

author: LehmanParty
body: Do you see how TLT rose during the initial crash and then plummeted after the sustained selloff? And then this week it went down with the market? The countercyclicals have been moving with cyclicals now and will be sold to maintain collateral requirements if requirements increase due to extreme volatility. There's a similar argument for gold and utilities. TLT doesn't have much more of an upside until the proposal of negative rates begins to appear. People would be more likely to flee to IG corporate bonds in the event of a scare than to treasuries, though this time there wouldn't be a sustained liquidity crunch due to a better preparedness for such an event.

author: rymor
body:
The way I see it, the only real risk is opportunity cost, but there are several aspects to that. 

If you have money in PIC, and the market crashes, the common shares might drop by only 5% to $9.50 while the market drops 30%. That’s good news, but what do you do now? 

If you think the market is set for a quick recovery, you probably pull the SPAC money out and put it into AAPL or AMZN, hoping for a 35% bounce. 

So, in that case, you would have been better off in cash when the market was shaky. The SPAC (eg PIC) will recover, to at least $10 and probably more. But it won’t give you a 35% recovery. So you’ve essentially given up 5% for your capital for no reason. 

 Now, if you think the market will be consistently bad, you might stick it out and try to play the quasi arbitrage game. The SPACs you purchase below their trust value might earn you 2-5% if a) the share price recovers, or b) you redeem your shares at the merger vote. 

If the latter, that could be a long wait. If the former, the overall market is likely to recover more quickly than PIC. PIC will bounce back to $10 right away, but AAPL is likely to hit $120 before PIC hits $11. 

So, that’s sort of the paradox of SPACs as I see it. I’m currently parked in QELL, DGNR, IPOF, CCIV, RBAC, RTP, and SOAC. 

If the market stays choppy for a few for months, which is likely (I don’t think we get any stimulus until Feb or so after a long drawn-out battle)... then SPACs might be a decent play... CCIV, SOAC, etc could announce a target and the price could jump 20% or more while the overall market is ranging. That’s a win. 

But if the market is really bad, they’ll probably wait to announce an agreement, so you don’t gain much there. And if the market does bounce back (eg sooner than expected stimulus), you’re probably better off in AMZN.

The best SPAC play IMO is to be in cash in choppy market, and if/when the market plummets, scoop up warrants and units of the better SPACs at discounted prices (eg $9.50 for tier one units; sub $1 warrants for the best management team SPACs). 

But then again, if you’re able to time the market that well, you could buy SHOP or LULU at deep discounts and do just as well.

author: mrh0057
body:
The stock market is way overvalued and you need to understand more of why.  You can look at things like P/E ratios and that but there is another elephant in the room right now people are ignoring.  Most of the world's population is getting older and there will be a significantly smaller number of people working per retiree and wages have been flat or going down.  Then you have increased expenses for housing and healthcare (US only).  There already is negative outflows for years and no one is talking about what happens as it accelerates as boomers retire.  The stock market started to go up significantly when the US switched from pension funds to 401k.  Granted there are other factors driving the economy but you now have a significant flow of new money into the market. 

BTW, bonds are sold in markets and auctions so if the rate is low that means a significant portion of the investment world thinks the economy isn't in great shape.  Have to ask yourself why are willing to lend money so cheaply.  The bond market is something like 3x bigger than the stock market.  So the bonds are saying we don't believe the current rally and why would they when corporate profits have been nearly flat since 2012 before COVID and now have decreased significantly.

See the earnings call for IDXX, revenue growth and vet visits are actually positive this year because despite the restrictions... people still care about their pets and more people WFH = more first time pet owners

LYV: What I learned is that most people don't care about social distancing and are ok with packing a venue to watch concerts and sports again. So many of the mom and pop shop venues are probably going to close due to $0 cash flow this year. As long as LYV can make it out alive until restrictions are lifted... the only competitor in there way will be pretty much AEG and they can continue its pre-COVID momentum. Warning... the stock hasn't dropped a lot for a company that is in a cash crunch and has +95% revenue decrease, which surprises me. E
What won't surprise me if the stock drops to $20 - $45 and I'll be a buyer.

V and MA: Should also accelerate growth once a vaccine is available and transactions are lifted. They should recover a big chunk of their spending volume and cross-border fees, but I think business travel is permanently impaired. Right now I'm a V holder, but I like PYPL a bit more as my favorite fintech.

author: coolcomfort123
body: baba and paypal for the win.

author: Dmoan
body: It on 11/5 AH, I like PYPL also but they are reporting tomorrow and will get lost in all this madness plus the stock has barely sold off

author: brereddit
body: If gdp spiked, PayPal will crush earnings

author: DenverNuggetz
body:
40 million+ users and growing at a large rate.

Add that to PayPal’s already large userbase....pypl isn’t going anywhere soon.

The company is a great play alongside SQ as the biggest threats to the large payment processors like V.

author: Dmoan
body: Cash app (owned by SQ) is beating Paypal and Venmo app (owned by Paypal). PayPal was very slow to add features to Venmo allowing Cash app to beat them

author: mulemoment
body:
Also, according to technical analysis, it's been way overbought this year and needs to correct. It looks like it'll stabilize at ~140, maybe ~120 with strong sell pressure.

Also they've been getting rewarded for revenue growth, but the revenue growth is from bitcoin which 1. they're barely profitable on and 2. are seeing a growth of competition in from companies like paypal.

author: PandaGodFliesToMoon
body: who is playing pypl and swks today? calls or puts?

author: Boomtown626
body:
Disagreed, I think they make more sense long-term, but reading your post just got me to go fractionally reduce exposure to MSFT, GOOGL, NFLX, and the chip-makers I have (AMD, NXPI, MRVL, SWKS, SOXX), because I want the cash available to buy the dip whenever this week's bloodbath happens, and I think reducing exposure there makes more sense in the short-term than reducing my holdings in the names that will be exposed to good vaccine news and good reopening news. 

Remember Moderna, Pfizer, and JNJ all have stage 3 vaccine trial results they plan to announce within the next month. If you wait until the news cycle starts reminding us, then you've already missed a bigger bounce than you can reasonably expect from this year's biggest tech winners over the next few weeks.
